## Process Scheduling
We now know the low level mechanisms involved in running processes, such as the possible states a process can occupy, and how the transitions between them occur, however we have not yet explored how an operating system determines when to change a process's state, and the high level policies used by the OS scheduler to manage these transitions. In this section, we will start to look that, introducing a variety of scheduling polices that have been developed over time.  
The origins of scheduling date back to before computer systems existed. Early scheduling techniques were adapted from the field of operations management and later applied o computing environments. This connection is not surprising, as borh assembly lines and computer systems share many of the same scheduling challenges. Efficiency is a central concern in borh domains, and the lessons learned from optimizing industrial processes have informed the evolution of computer scheduling algorithms.

## First In, First Out (FIFO)
The simplest scheduling algorithm we can implement is known as First In, First Out scheduling, also referred to as First Come, First Serve (FCFS). FIFO has several advantageous characteristics: it is conceptually straightforward, making it easy to implement, and under certain assumptions, it performs reasonably well.

Let's consider a scenario where three jobs (A, B, and C) arrive in the system at approximately the same time (T=0). Since FIFO must choose an order, we will assume that job A arrives just slightly before job B, which in turn arrives just before job C. Additionally, each job requires 10 seconds of execution time. What would be the average time for these three jobs to complete under FIFO scheduling?

To answer such questions, especially as the complexity increases, it is often helpful to visualize the execution timeline. In this case, something like the following:

![](data:image/png;base64,)

From the image above, you can see that A finished at T=10, B at T=20, and C at T=30. Thus, the average turnaround time for the three jobs is simply:  
 

![](data:image/png;base64,)

Formally, turnaround time is defined as the difference between the time a job completes and the time it first arrives in the system. In this example, since all jobs arrive simultaneously at T=0, the turnaround time is equivalent to the completion time for each job. However, as we begin to relax the assumption of simultaneous arrival, these calculations will be more nuanced.

Turnaround time is a key performance metric, which will be our main focus here. Another metric of interest in scheduling is fairness, which can be quantified using measures such as Jain's Fairness Index ([https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fairness_measure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fairness_measure)). Performance and fairness often exist in tension within scheduling algorithms. For instance, an algorithm optimized for performance may lead to certain jobs being delayed or starved, thus decreasing fairness. This trade-off illustrates the inherent complexity of scheduling decisions, where perfect outcomes are rarely achievable.

### Problems with FIFO

The FIFO scheduling described above seems to work well, however lets now consider a similar situation with three jobs (A, B, C), but this time A runs for 100 seconds while B and C run for 10 each. In this case, the timeline looks something like the following:

Despite jobs B and C still being the same length, the average turnaround time is now much higher:

![](data:image/png;base64,)

This phenomenon is commonly known as the convoy effect which occurs when a group of short-running processes or resource consumers are forces to wait behind a long-running, resource-intensive process. In such cases, the heavyweight process monopolizes the CPU or other system resources, causing significant delays for the shorter processes.

A real world analogy for the convoy effect is the experience of standing in a single line at the supermarket, only to find yourself behind a customer with three shopping trolleys filled to the brim. The delay in processing the large order causes everyone behind them to wait longer than necessary. Similarly, in a scheduling context, the system's resources are tied up by the larger process, creating inefficiency for the smaller tasks waiting in line.

This effect highlights a key limitation of certain scheduling algorithms which do not differentiate between processes based on their expected execution time or resource demands. In such scenarios, the overall system performance can suffer as smaller, quicker tasks are unnecessarily delayed, leading to higher average turnaround times and reduced system responsiveness. Avoiding the convoy effect is one of the motivations for more sophisticated scheduling algorithms that prioritize fairness and efficiency by giving appropriate attention to shorter or less resource-intensive tasks.

### Shortest Job First (SJF)

A remarkably simple solution to this problem comes from an approach originally borrowed from the field of operations research and later adapted for job scheduling in computer systems. This method is called Shortest Job First (SJF) , and the name itself succinctly conveys the entire scheduling policy: the system prioritizes the job with the shortest execution time, followed by the next shortest, continuing in this manner until all jobs are completed.

The rationale behind SJF is grounded in optimizing efficiency, particularly in minimizing the average turnaround time for a set of jobs. By prioritizing shorter tasks, SJF ensures that jobs complete as quickly as possible, preventing long processes from delaying the execution of shorter ones. This approach is ideal in scenarios where job lengths are known or can be accurately predicted.

Given a set of jobs waiting to run, SJF selects the job with the shortest execution time and this job runs to completion. If we consider the second example above with 3 waiting jobs, the timeline now looks something like this.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

And the average turnaround time is dramatically reduced:

![](data:image/png;base64,)

Given the assumption that all jobs arrive at the same time, SJF is indeed an optimal scheduling algorithm. However, if we now assume that jobs B and C arrive after job A has started, we have a problem. Job A will still run to completion before jobs B and C start. Let's say A arrives at T=0 and needs to run for 100 seconds, whereas B and C arrive at T=10 and each need to run for 10 seconds. In this case the average turnaround time is:

![](data:image/png;base64,)

If you are unsure how we get this result, remember that the turnaround time for each job is the difference between the time a job completes and the time it first arrives in the system. So, the turnaround time for A is 100-0, B is 110-10, C is 120-10

## Shortest Time-to-Completion First (STCF)

The Shortest Time-to-Completion First (STCF) algorithm addresses this issue with SJF. When a new job enters the system, the STCF scheduler evaluates all the jobs currently in the system, including the newly arrived job. To determine which has the least remaining execution time. It then schedules the job with the shortest time left. If a newly arrived job has a shorter time remaining than the currently running process, STCF will pre-empt the running process and give the CPU to the new job.

In our example, if job A is running and jobs B and C enter the system with shorter remaining execution times, the STCF scheduler would immediately interrupt job A's execution. It would then prioritize B and C, running them  to completion before allowing A to resume and finish its remaining execution. Only once the shorter jobs have completed will A be Scheduled again to use the CPU and finish its remaining time.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

The result is a much improved average turnaround time of 50 seconds:

![](data:image/png;base64,)

### Problems with STCF

This pre-emptive behaviour of STCF ensures that jobs with shorter completion times are prioritized, which minimizes the overall average turnaround time. However, this also introduces additional complexity, such as the overhead of frequent context switching when jobs of varying lengths are submitted. Additionally, while STCF optimizes or turnaround time, it can lead to longer jobs being starved if shorter jobs continue to arrive, delaying the completion of longer-running processes.

If we had perfect knowledge of job lengths, assuming jobs only utilized the CPU and our sole performance metric was turnaround time, the STCF scheduling policy would be ideal. STCF minimizes the average turnaround time by prioritizing shorter jobs. In fact, this approach was quite effective in early batch computing systems, where jobs were submitted in bulk and there was no requirement for real-time interactivity. However with the advent of time-sharing systems, the need for interactive performance became critical, and this fundamentally changed how scheduling policies were evaluated.

With time sharing, users interacted with the system directly through terminals, expecting prompt feedback. This shift led to the development of a new key metric: response time. We define response time as the duration between the moment a job arrives in the system and the first time it is scheduled to run.

While STCF and similar algorithms excel at minimizing turnaround time, they perform poorly when it comes to response time. For example, if three jobs arrive simultaneously, the third job must wait for the first two to complete entirely before even beginning execution. Although this is efficient from a turnaround time perspective, it results in unacceptably long response times, which significantly degrades the system's interactivity.

Consider a scenario where a user is working at a terminal, typing commands, and the system takes several seconds to respond because other jobs are ahead in the queue. Such delays are highly undesirable in interactive environments, where users expect near-instantaneous feedback from the system. Thus, while STCF is optimal for batch processing, it is inadequate for interactive systems, highlighting the need for scheduling algorithms that balance both turnaround and response times effectively.

## Round-Robin (RR)

To address the limitations of simple scheduling algorithms, we introduce a new method called Round-Robin (RR) scheduling. The core concept behind RR is straightforward: instead of allowing a job to run to completion, RR allocates each job a fixed time slice (also known as a scheduling quantum). After the time slice expires, the scheduler pre-empts the running job and switches to the next one in the queue. This process repeats continuously until all jobs are completed. Due to its cyclical nature, RR is sometimes referred to as time-slicing.

Let's explore RR in more detail with an example. Suppose three jobs - A, B, and C - arrive simultaneously and each requires 5 seconds of CPU time to complete. A SJF scheduler would run each job sequentially until completion, processing them one at a time. In contrast, RR with a time slice of 1 seconds would cycle between the jobs more rapidly, giving each job a brief period of CPU time before moving on to the next.

The difference between these two approaches is evident in their response times - the time from when a job arrives until it first starts executing. For RR, the average response time is:

![](data:image/png;base64,)

In comparison, the average response time for SJF is:

![](data:image/png;base64,)

This example demonstrates how RR can significantly improve response times by ensuring that each job gets some CPU time early on, rather than waiting for other jobs to finish. However, this improvement comes at the cost of increased context switching, which can add overhead to the system. Choosing an appropriate time slice is thus critical: too small, and the system spends excessive time switching between jobs; too large, and it may behave similarly to FCFS, losing the responsiveness advantage.

## Process Priority

In modern operating systems, process priority is a key factor that determines the order in which processes are scheduled for execution. The priority of a process reflets its importance relative to other processes, with higher-priority processes generally receiving more immediate access to CPU time than lower-priority ones. This system helps the OS balance the needs of different types of processes, ensuring critical tasks are handled promptly while less urgent tasks are deferred when necessary.

## Priority levels and examples

Processes are often categorized into high, medium, and low priority levels:

### High priority processes

These typically involve system-critical tasks that must be executed promptly to maintain system stability or performance. Examples include processes that handle real-time events, interrupt servicing, or security monitoring. In a multimedia environment, processes related to video playback or audio processing may also be assigned high priority to avoid noticeable delays.

### Medium-priority processes

These include regular user applications that are important but do not require immediate execution. Word processors, web browsers, or background data synchronization services might fall into this category. They need to be responsive but are not as time sensitive as high-priority processes.

### Low-priority processes:

These processes can afford to wait longer for CPU time. Examples include background tasks like system maintenance (E.g., disk defragmentation or file indexing) and large data backups. These processes are often deferred until higher-priority tasks are completed, minimizing their impact on overall system responsiveness.

## Priority Queues and Scheduling

To handle processes with different priority levels, many operating systems use a multilevel queue scheduling approach. In this system, separate queues are maintained for each priority level:

- High-priority processes are placed in the top queue and receive the most CPU time.
- Medium-priority processes are placed in a middle queue, receiving CPU time after high-priority tasks have been scheduled.
- Low-priority processes reside in a lower queue and are only scheduled when no higher-priority processes are ready to run.

The operating system schedules processes from the highest priority queue first, ensuring that critical tasks are addressed immediately. If a high-priority process arrives while a lower-priority process is running, pre-emption occurs, meaning the lower-priority process is paused, and the higher-priority one is executed.

### Priority Scheduling in Windows

In Windows, processes are assigned a priority level from a predefined range of 0 to 31, with higher numbers representing higher priority. The system kernel uses this priority range to schedule processes, ensuring that real-time tasks (with priorities above 15) are executed immediately. Regular user applications typically have priorities between 1 and 15. Windows also employs dynamic priority adjustment temporarily boosting the priority of I/O-bound or interactive processes to improve system responsiveness, especially for tasks like user input handling.

### Priority Scheduling in Linux

In Linux, processes priority is handles through a system of nice values and real-time scheduling policies. The nice value ranges from -20 to 19 , where lower values represent higher priorities. By default, regular processes are assigned a nice value of -, while more critical processes may be assigned lower (higher-priority) values. Linux also supports real-time scheduling policies such as SCHED_FIFO and SCHED_RR, which are reserved for processes requiring deterministic execution time, like real-time applications. These processes are given strict priority over regular tasks.

Both Windows and Linux balance priorities dynamically to ensure system responsiveness while managing background tasks efficiently. By adjusting priority levels based on process characteristics and user activity, they strive to offer a seamless and efficient multitasking environment.
